data.title: Richard Loe
data.text:
In article <5hrek2$a...@ccshst05.cs.uoguelph.ca>,

hagg...@moo.u.gwelf says...

>Miguel <MIG...@ms.com> wrote:

>:Talking of Richard Loe, whatever happened to his front row partner Steve

>:McDowell.

>I think Loe actually beat out McDowell for Loosehead for the AllBlacks a

>couple of years ago. Maybe that had something to do with it.

Steve McDowell opened a bar down here in Wellington in 1995 just

a few months before the RWC, and he also played a few games for

Wellington in the NPC. He looked like he was keen to get back

into it, and certainly looked in shape - not an ounce of fat on

the guy.

The bar shut soon after that though, and I don't think the venture

was successful. I haven't seen him around since, but I assume

that the business of earning a living has kept him out of the

game. It's a pity, since he could easily have made a Super-12

team I reckon.

Cheers,

Paul.

--

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Paul Waite NZ Rugby news, info, and opinion at

pau...@ihug.co.nz http://homepages.ihug.co.nz/~paulwa/haka.html

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Koos wrote:

<some shit>

Merely because the SAfs have a long and rich history of using everything

possible to enhance their chances (including anabolic steroids) doesn't

mean that the rest of us follow suit.

Steve McDowell was on "The Footy Show" the other night, and didn't look

all that different to me. He was a bit smaller, but we never have snide

little comments when yot see a rugby player run to fat after

retirement. Remember, Koos, the dude was NZ heavyweight judo champion,

and they do have drug testing in judo. No suspicion has ever been

attached to McDowell at any time in the past, and all of this crap

innuendo about his size in an insult to a great prop.

Currently, he is a fitness consultant in Auckland, which requires a

sightly different fitness (and therefore results in a different

bodyshape) from either rugby or judo.

I like the odd bit of wild speculation - it's one of the reasons I read

this group, but this bit goes all the way into being malicious.

Pull your head in, Koos.

Cheers

Tim

On Sat, 05 Apr 1997 12:56:25 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

wrote:

<<Merely because the SAfs have a long and rich history of using

everything

>possible to enhance their chances (including anabolic steroids) doesn't

>mean that the rest of us follow suit.>>>

"Walter Little"....oh shit sorry.....did'nt say that.

<<>I like the odd bit of wild speculation - it's one of the reasons I

read

>this group, but this bit goes all the way into being malicious. >>>

I never heard you when SA'ns were smeared pitch black in this group

over the months. Are you new on the group or do you just react when

New Zealanders are the subject?

(Put differently: We SA'ns know how you feel, we know....

And sometimes some of us just decide to give it back in the same way.)

By the way, being NZ judo champion does not mean all that much in

terms of drugs testing does it?

Take a look at the Olympics. See how many national champs gets caught

out in different countries.

Koos wrote:

>

> On Sat, 05 Apr 1997 12:56:25 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

> wrote:

>

> <<Merely because the SAfs have a long and rich history of using

> everything

> >possible to enhance their chances (including anabolic steroids) doesn't

> >mean that the rest of us follow suit.>>>

>

> "Walter Little"....oh shit sorry.....did'nt say that.

Koos, it was ephedrine from a cold medicine, not sustanolol. He says he

made a dumb mistake, and I am prepared to give him the benefit of the

doubt. To be petty, when drug testing was introduced into rugby in a

serious way, one country in particular stood out for specifically

anabolic steroid abuse (though looking at the NZ cricket team, I'm glad

they didn't test the rugby players for marijuana use).

> <<>I like the odd bit of wild speculation - it's one of the reasons I

> read

> >this group, but this bit goes all the way into being malicious. >>>

>

> I never heard you when SA'ns were smeared pitch black in this group

> over the months. Are you new on the group or do you just react when

> New Zealanders are the subject?

Both - I don't think that the SAFs need me to hold their hands. I have

posted the odd complementary thing about SAF rugby and players, but

Steve McDowell in particular has been a favourite player of mine for

years.

> By the way, being NZ judo champion does not mean all that much in

> terms of drugs testing does it?

> Take a look at the Olympics. See how many national champs gets caught

> out in different countries.

I take your point, but they do get caught (I know, not all of them do).

Drug testing is better than no drug testing, is the argument here.

NZ has a pretty good record for performance-enhancing drug use. I can

only think of 3 people (including Waltza) done in all sport in recent

years.

Cheers

Tim

Koos wrote:

> You forgot the poison.

> And the crooked reffs and linemen.

Good on ya, Koos. Providing your own ammunition.

As far as the food-poisoning thing goes, no-one can prove the thing one

way or the other. The timing may be suspicious, but it may also be

coincidence. Who knows? The result is in the book, and that is what

counts.

In the case of refs/linesmen. there is only one case that I can think of

in the long history of rugby against "the Enemy" (SAf, in case you

didn't know we called you that) that a ref made a difference to results

in a huge way. Dude with a name like a sneeze in the 1976 AB tour

(Bezoudenheit?? My Afrikaans spelling is probably dreadful).

Other than that (which was amazingly biased - really beyond belief), the

ABs should be good enough to beat the SAFs no matter who's refs we use,

whether the difference is in interpretation or (I am sure unconcious)

bias. And conversely, the SAFs should be good enough to beat the ABs

over here with our refs.

Neutrals are the right thing to do, though.

Chris Hackney wrote:

>

> What did he (Bezuidenhout ??) do? I don't remember any linesmen scandals during that

> tour. But then I am SAf. In any case, nothing could be as weird as when a linesman

> literally "sicked" his dog (German Shepherd) on one of my teammates during a high school

> game. But then again, maybe Bezuidenhout couldn't sneak his dog into the stadium.

>

> Chris

No shit!! "Sic him, Rover" (or whatever the equivalent is in your part

of the world) while he was playing?

Dude wasn't the linesman, he was the ref (for the last three test of the

series). IMHO, the decisions that he made during that test series

actually changed what the probable result of the series would have been

- to a draw, rather than a series win to the ABs. But then, I am a

Kiwi, and we lost the series 3-1.

As an example, in the last test, Bruce Robertson (easily the best centre

NZ has ever produced) received the ball from Kevin Everleigh, and

chipped the SAf fullback. Who then (really blatantly) obstructed him as

Robertson went round him (the fullbacks' name was also Robertson, just

to add to the confusion), and the try was lost. Clearest possible case

for a penalty try - but the ruling was a penalty. How clear was it? Dr

Craven said it should have been a penalty try.

(So did John Reason, but he is the biggest wank-stain ever to put pen to

paper about rugby, so we won't count him).

This is not to drag up things that (really) no longer matter, but just

for info purposes. Other than Bezoudenheit, it really takes a lot of

bias in the average rugby game to change the result, and I can't think

of another case (off-hand) where bias probably made a difference.

Ian Wilson wrote:

> Well, usually SAfs are caught out by their own governing bodies. The

> fact that NZ has less cases could just mean your governing body is

> pretty pathetic at doing their job, or it could be that NZ actually do

> have less cases of steroid use. Then again, the fact that SA has such a higher population than NZ could also be a factor, couldn't it?

>

> Your statement is a load of #@$%@& and doesn't even warrant the

> attention of a 5 year old with nothing better to do!

>

> Ian

The NZRFU and the SARFU are probably the two most professional govering

bodies in rugby. NZ and SA have a (roughly) comparable number of

top-class players, and there has seemed to me to be more SAfs caught

specifically for anabolic steroid abuse than NZers.

Our testing programme is equally as good as yours. I actually put it

down to NZ having a (slight) bias in favour of smaller, more mobile

tight forwards, when compared to SAf, meaning there is not the perceived

need for absolute size and strength, and therefore less pressure on the

top players to "bulk up".

It is only a theory, though, and I am quite willing to have it

disproved. It mainly comes from watching SA packs coming on to the

field over the years and thinking "Fuck, they're big" - BTW, this is

just meant as a comment on the size of the forwards, not a dig at any

medical intake.

As for the 5-yr old bit, at least I had an argument and facts to back up

my theory, rather than just going maybe...maybe...maybe.

Regards

Tim

On Wed, 09 Apr 1997 15:51:10 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

wrote:

<<>This is not to drag up things that (really) no longer matter, but

just

>for info purposes. Other than Bezoudenheit, it really takes a lot of

>bias in the average rugby game to change the result, and I can't think

>of another case (off-hand) where bias probably made a difference.>>>

Read a piece the other day of way, way back when SA actually broke off

rugby relations with NZ after some Boks in NZ overheard some All Black

players telling the reff for the coming test where and how to penalise

the Boks.

It was the infamous Jaap Bekker/ Skinner tour.

Craven was then manager and a desicion was actually taken not to play

NZ again, it was written.

The thing was sorted out, however.

But as you so elegantly said: <<<This is not to drag up things that

(really) no longer matter, but just for info purposes>>>>

Then of course there was that bit of controversy in 1981 in the last

test that saw the Boks lose the series instead of winning it.

Tim Scrivens wrote:....

> As an example, in the last test, Bruce Robertson (easily the

> best centre NZ has ever produced) received the ball from

> Kevin Everleigh, and chipped the SAf fullback. ....

Yes, Bruce was a marvel, wasn't he? Even looking at old videos now, he

still looks great.

I clearly remember another incident in this nauseating display of the

most prejudiced refereeing display of all time. NZ were awarded a

penalty, Sid Going lined up the ball for a kick, the ball fell over, and

the referee reversed the penalty on the grounds that NZ were wasting

time. Abominable. Still, it's all the fault of the pathetic old

dinosaurs on the NZRFU. SA offered them neutral referees and the

deadshit old pricks turned them down! Now they may rank as the single

greatest act of stupidity by any Union anywhere in the world!

I spoke to Sid about this very incident when he was on tour promoting

his book. He just shook his head and said "We knew after we won the

second test they just wouldn't allow us to win the third."

And don't worry Koos, I haven't forgotten the food poisoning.

- Rick Boyd

Ian Jennings wrote:

>

> This stuff is pretty hard to substantiate. I recall the tour quite well

> - the ABs were not that shit-hot. They lost to the top four provincial

> sides in SA on tour - in comparison to the Lions of two years previously

> who went through a 22 match tour of SA without looking like losing until

> the final test. Of course it was probably all just cheating refs,

> though.

>

> Ian

True, hard to substantiate. However, I have looked at the film of the

incident I referred to a number of times over the years, and I still

can't put that decision down to anything other than bias - it was that

obvious. The ABs did lose a few provincial matches, but, like the SA

teams over here, were never anything but totally tough in the tests.

Oh yeah, and while we're on the subject of the 76 tour, the touring

party included one player of the all-time 5 dirtiest players ever to

play for the ABs (Billy Bush). And we (modern) think Richard Loe is

bad.

That was a great Lions team - the one that is coming over is (I think)

heading into a shitstorm (on the field, I mean).

Ian Jennings wrote:

> This stuff is pretty hard to substantiate. I recall the tour

> quite well - the ABs were not that shit-hot.

True. They were a pretty average team. There was also some strange

selection decisions. The team seriously lacked a goal kicker. They took

a bloke called Kit Fawcett, who made history with the diplomatic

statement, "I intend to score more off the field than on it". The All

Blacks ended up using a converted flyhalf in Duncan Robertson at

fullback, as I recall.

NZ also found it very hard to understad a lot of SA interpretations. In

those days tours were much less frequent, domestic competitions were

very insular, and countries very much had their own ways of doing

things. A neutral referee would have evened this out a lot.

Given all this, you only have to wonder why the ref had to resort to

such abysmal prejudice. SA were quite capable of winning the series fair

and square. To NZ's credit they came very close to drawing the series,

if not actually winning it.

Most New Zealanders who saw the series and who know anything at all

about rugby believe to this day that but for that one referee, the All

Blacks would almost certainly have drawn that series.

- Rick Boyd

On Sat, 12 Apr 1997 23:51:24 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

wrote:

<<>Koos, you are confused.<>>>

About what?

I said:

1. Flippie was big with fat

2. Bull Allen has a huge neck with no fat on it.

You tell me the weight of some Fijan and say I am confused.

Did you aim to present a self fulfilling prophecy?

Because you delivered one and I now am confused.

I do not know off hand the stats of the Bok forwards.

The locks are the biggest I suppose. They are Wiese and Andrews.

Andrews is thin and Wiese is a bit pudgy, though he is less of a fatty

now than when he started.

I watch them in the line outs and they look to me to be more or less

the same size height as the AB locks with Wiese a bit thicker all

over, although he is probably not as tall as Andrews, Jones and

Brooke.

Lomu is different.

He is a wing. He is tall and very muscular.

Looks like a body builder.

Our wings are generally much smaller.

Like Olivier who looks like a small body builder.

And Stephen Brink who looks (as does Cullen) like a high school kid

with lots of speed.

(By the way, the absence of Lomu and Vidiri still not able to play for

the AB's will hopefully mean that Brink will be a Bok wing this year.

Specially against the Lions who have smallish wings as well. Brink

will hopefully be able to bring real speed to the SA outfield.)

Was the question about the SA stats rhetoric or do you really want it?

I by the way do not always trust the figures given out.

Saw twice now on TV Stephen Brink's weight given as 90 kg.

I doubt very much if he is that big.

If he is 90 kg then Vidiri must be about 140 kg.

Koos wrote:

>

> On Sat, 12 Apr 1997 23:51:24 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

> wrote:

>

> <<>Koos, you are confused.<>>>

>

> About what?

>

> I said:

> 1. Flippie was big with fat

> 2. Bull Allen has a huge neck with no fat on it.

>

> You tell me the weight of some Fijan and say I am confused.

>

My original comment was that for every Flippie I could point you at, you

could point out a big fat prick that plays rugby in NZ. My original

thought was just an impression, and I'm buggered if I know how or why

the Bull got involved.

> Did you aim to present a self fulfilling prophecy?

>

See above. I was doing it before you did, but you did it anyway.

> Because you delivered one and I now am confused.

>

> I watch them in the line outs and they look to me to be more or less

> the same size height as the AB locks with Wiese a bit thicker all

> over, although he is probably not as tall as Andrews, Jones and

> Brooke.

>

I heard Andrews was 6' 8". Maybe someone could enlighten the both of

us.

> Lomu is different.

> He is a wing. He is tall and very muscular.

> Looks like a body builder.

> Our wings are generally much smaller.

Yeah, but look at the nutcase (James Small - I mean it in an admiring

sense). Not incredibly tall, but very powerful, and able to cope pretty

well with Jonah 1 on 1 (or at least, better than anyone else - lot of

respect for that).

> Like Olivier who looks like a small body builder.

> And Stephen Brink who looks (as does Cullen) like a high school kid

> with lots of speed.

>

My point was that Lomu is the third (equal) tallest man in the ABs,

which is a bit weird for a wing (would expect it to go locks, No 8,

flankers and then to be fairly random). But none of the ABs make 6'6",

which is (relatively) short.

> (By the way, the absence of Lomu and Vidiri still not able to play for

> the AB's will hopefully mean that Brink will be a Bok wing this year.

> Specially against the Lions who have smallish wings as well. Brink

> will hopefully be able to bring real speed to the SA outfield.)

Depends who we (the ABs) play? Shouldn't really. It is better to try

to pick players to take the game to the opposition, rather than to react

to their selections with your own, I would have thought.

>

> Was the question about the SA stats rhetoric or do you really want it?

Nah, I want it for sure.

>

> I by the way do not always trust the figures given out.

> Saw twice now on TV Stephen Brink's weight given as 90 kg.

You're not wrong. They say Cullen is 85 kilos. Come on !!!

> I doubt very much if he is that big.

> If he is 90 kg then Vidiri must be about 140 kg.

See, another big fat Fijian, and back to our original start. Sort of a

circular arguement.

On Tue, 15 Apr 1997 18:12:36 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

wrote:

<<<>> (By the way, the absence of Lomu and Vidiri still not able to

play for

>> the AB's will hopefully mean that Brink will be a Bok wing this year.

>> Specially against the Lions who have smallish wings as well. Brink

>> will hopefully be able to bring real speed to the SA outfield.)

>

>Depends who we (the ABs) play? Shouldn't really. It is better to try

>to pick players to take the game to the opposition, rather than to react

>to their selections with your own, I would have thought.>>>

Put it this way: In 1995 it probably was proved that when you play

against an on form Lomu, an Underwoord is not good enough.

So: Vidiri will run over Brink. In a test you must have confidence

that in a 1 on 1 situation your wing will 9 times out of 10 stop his

opponent. Also in a short space so he cannot get the ball 7 yards out

and crash over.

This reminds me of a bit I read written by an English rugby writer

(cannot remember who).

He writes he spoke with the long ago Bok Flip Nel who said: " Any test

should end with a score of 0 - 0 because you have two perfect teams

against each other. But human beings what they are, they tend to slip

up from time to time and make mistakes. And that is where the pionts

are scored."

Koos wrote:

>

> On Tue, 15 Apr 1997 18:12:36 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

> wrote:

>

>>Depends who we (the ABs) play? Shouldn't really. It is better to try

>>to pick players to take the game to the opposition, rather than to react

> >to their selections with your own, I would have thought.>>>

>

> Put it this way: In 1995 it probably was proved that when you play

> against an on form Lomu, an Underwoord is not good enough.

>

Yeah, but surely England could do better than Underwood. Not a rated

player for me, and you (SA) wouldn't ever put anyone of that standard on

the field.

> So: Vidiri will run over Brink. In a test you must have confidence

> that in a 1 on 1 situation your wing will 9 times out of 10 stop his

> opponent. Also in a short space so he cannot get the ball 7 yards out

> and crash over.

Brink is cool, but NZ a while back had a tradition of fielding a back

three who couldn't tackle to save themselves (two because they were (my

opinion only) windy, and one because he didn't really know how). We

played them because (especially in the case of the fullback) they may

cost us 10 points a game between them, but they consistently scored 15.

I thought last year, and in the World Cup, the SA defence did the best

job on Lomu by mobbing him whenever possible, and giving him no room.

Brink is fast and skilful, and surely deserves a chance of trying to see

if hecan run round Vindiri a few times, just to even things up.

I still reckon you should pick your best players, and if the opposition

fields a Lomu, and you have a Terry Wright to oppose him, you have a

game plan that plays on Terrys' strengths, and Jonahs' weaknesses.

>

> This reminds me of a bit I read written by an English rugby writer

> (cannot remember who).

> He writes he spoke with the long ago Bok Flip Nel who said: " Any test

> should end with a score of 0 - 0 because you have two perfect teams

> against each other. But human beings what they are, they tend to slip

> up from time to time and make mistakes. And that is where the pionts

> are scored."

True enuff.

Koos wrote in a message to All:

K> This reminds me of a bit I read written by an English rugby

K> writer (cannot remember who).

K> He writes he spoke with the long ago Bok Flip Nel who said:

K> " Any test should end with a score of 0 - 0 because you have

K> two perfect teams against each other. But human beings what

K> they are, they tend to slip up from time to time and make

K> mistakes. And that is where the pionts are scored."

Evenly matched rather than perfect is probably a better choice of

words.

Nel's attitude probably isn't unusual given that evenly

matched games would be their hardest games.

But I think his theory would be shot to threads by a team

running the other team off the park. Like Auckland did to

Transvaal, for example.

Rgds George

email: geo...@galaxy.gen.nz

On Mon, 21 Apr 1997 22:58:15 +1200, Tim Scrivens <scri...@xtra.co.nz>

wrote:

<<>It was a joke !!! Both halves, I thought. Do you guys actually

think

>that Norling cheated? We were always a bit disappointed when we got

>him, because we thought his interpretations were often hard on the ABs?>>>>

Some people here thinks he did.

I don't.

But the discussion flows out of allegations of a SA reff crooking in

the 70's and a request to SA people on the group to point to any like

incidents that may have gone against SA

<<<2. At least Clive didn't get a gold watch.>>>

This is usually code for: "Louis Luyt bought Bevan with a gold watch

that he presented to him in public, to crook and let the Boks win

against the French in 1995".

Do YOU actually believe this crap?

Ferdi wrote:

>> [...2. At least Clive didn't get a gold watch.]

> This is usually code for: "Louis Luyt bought Bevan with a gold

> watch that he presented to him in public, to crook and let the

> Boks win against the French in 1995".

>

> Do YOU actually believe this crap?

No, I don't believe it. But I do believe Louis Luyt to the be the most

arrogant and offensive person in the history of rugby.

What it is ACTUALLY code for, is: "Louis Luyt showed horrendously poor

judgement and extremely questionable taste in presenting a gift to an

individual referee who had earlier refereed a very close game that

resulted in a controversial win to the Springboks. This gift cast

suspicions both on the SA administration and the referee which were

hopefully unwarranted but could easily have been avoided with an ounce

of tact. The insensitivity of this award was marked by the entire

referees contingent walking out of the dinner."

- Rick Boyd
